docs.title: Welcome to the heaven of failures!
docs.text:
This is my lab notebook for e-textiles: a place to document experiments and experiences.

This site is part of my Masters studies in Vilnius Academy of Arts (VDA) Fashion Design programme. Master studies supervisors: creative work Doc. Dainius Bendikas, research Doc. Dr. Deima Katinaitė.

In 2023, I completed Fabricademy course, which greatly inspired me to continue on this path. I sincerely recommend this course to anyone who is curious and wants to expand their knowledge in the field of textile technology.

During the course, I met some very inspiring people who showed me so much that it was simply impossible to stop :) I am very grateful to my mentor Nuria Robles Miguelez, who taught me how to document creative processes. Inspired by her and Fabricademy course, I created this site so that failures and successes would be visible and unforgettable.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
I'm not a coder, so I'll post some ready-made codes and links here, which took me a while to collect into one pile.

James Willett provides very clear steps to follow. Tuttorials on Youtube and his website.

Download starter package to build.

Thomas Wilde created very cozy and clear video with nice musical background.

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
This site is build on GitHub platform using Material for MkDocs theme. It took me one week to remember and understand how to build the site, but the effort was worth it and now I can share some tips. Here you will find codes and programs for Windows.

Visual Studio Code and extensions

  • Git Graph
  • YAML by Red Hat
  • Material Icon Theme

Window PowerShell

Git

Python 3.8 or higher

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Create project folder. Here you can add the downloaded files from starter package.

Local path: C:\Users\user\project

Type "System Properties" and go to Environment Variables...Path...Edit...Add New (push OK in every window)

Visual Studio CodeTo publish on GitHubPowerShell
  1. cd "C:\Users\user\project"
  2. where python
  3. python -m venv venv
  4. .\venv\Scripts\activate
  5. pip --version
  6. pip install mkdocs-material
  7. mkdocs serve
  1. git add .
  2. commit -m $'Setting up for CI deploy
  3. git push origin main

To clean the cash * pip cache purge

docs.title: Markdown
docs.text:
Here you will find some markdown examples.

int sensorPin = A0;   // select the input pin for the potentiometer
int ledPin = 13;      // select the pin for the LED
int sensorValue = 0;  // variable to store the value coming from the sensor

int sensorPin = A0;   // select the input pin for the potentiometer
int ledPin = 13;      // select the pin for the LED
int sensorValue = 0;  // variable to store the value coming from the sensor
code with title
int sensorPin = A0;   // select the input pin for the potentiometer
int ledPin = 13;      // select the pin for the LED
int sensorValue = 0;  // variable to store the value coming from the sensor
Method Description GET :material-check: Fetch resource PUT :material-check-all: Update resource DELETE :material-close: Delete resource

docs.title: How to markdown site navigation
docs.text:
- Home: index.md
  - Folder:
      - project1: folder/project1.md
      - project2: folder/project2.md
      - project3: folder/project3.md

docs.title: How to fetch images
Experiment №001
docs.text: Alice is full of linguistic play, puns, and parodies.[45] According to Gillian Beer, Carroll's play with language evokes the feeling of words for new readers: they "still have insecure edges and a nimbus of nonsense blurs the sharp focus of terms".[46] The literary scholar Jessica Straley, in a work about the role of evolutionary theory in Victorian children's literature, argues that Carroll's focus on language prioritises humanism over scientism by emphasising language's role in human self-conception.
